medical_history.chief_complaint: Chronic unilateral thoracic pain and incontinence.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient had constant pain under her left breast for as long as she could remember, probably since adolescence. The pain worsened over time and spread horizontally to involve a band on the entire left side of the chest. The pain ranged in severity from 4 to 9 on a scale of 0 to 10, improving when lying down and not altered by coughing, straining, or palpation. It had not been relieved by physical therapy, chiropractic management, or medications including gabapentin and transdermal lidocaine. She reported occasional left groin and sacral pain, intermittent numbness in the left leg, bilateral foot pain, and episodic fecal and urinary incontinence.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Severe bilateral hearing loss, mild hypoproliferative anemia, hypertension, hypothyroidism, hypercholesterolemia, gastritis, attention deficit–hyperactivity disorder, mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, dysthymia, and severe fatigue. Previous fractures of the arms, repair of a rectal fistula, and additional minor surgical procedures.
medical_history.family_history: Mother died of multiple myeloma, father died of congestive heart failure and dementia; brother died of pulmonary fibrosis. A daughter had colon cancer; another son survived testicular cancer; another son has Asperger’s syndrome and mental retardation. No family history of neurologic or pain conditions.
medical_history.social_history: Retired nurse practitioner, lived with husband in Massachusetts. Smoked cigarettes for decades, did not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs.
